reviews.review_msg: Dimitri is an engaging prof who is well versed in his subject.  He's always willing to help, and a fair marker. Took this class on his field school, and would definately recommend him.
Not bad. I'm not a history student but I took this class as part of the Greece field school and still managed to do ok...it was worth it for Greece.

Dimitri is a great, wonderful, helpful person who will probably become a great prof - in the future. Right now, he's still too new to it. Essay q's were a bit vague. He compares the US and Bush to the Romans a LOT. Bottom line, though, is that compared to my interest level (extremely high) this course disappointed me.
This was the worst history class i've ever taken. Needs to go easy on the marking, this only an undergrad class. He is not helping to attract students to the hellenic studies program.

Horrible professor.  Like someone said, he marks like we're doing our PHD's.  I don't know anyone who is happy with him.  The language barrier is a problem.  I was also shocked to hear him spout **** remarks and then joke "don't quote me on this".  I will never take him again.  His comments on papers are harsh and the topics are nonsensical.

Absolutely ridiculous. Nothing could have been gained or learned from this class. No organization, lecutres were all over the place. The worst history class (if it can be called that)I have taken by far. This guy is totally out of it.

Really glad I took one of Paul's Italian film courses. This course on Italian style comedy was great. He takes a really innovative approach to reading history through film and teaches you how to analyze evidence in ways that other profs just don't. He was also amazing through the switch to remote learning and is really responsive to student needs.
Very Dry and Boring. Want's to hear exactly what he says. Not very helpfull overall. I will be avoiding classes with  him.
